dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, you know, Uber dropped a pretty big bombshell recently, didn't they? Said they'd comply with California's AB5 and reclassify their drivers as employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, you know, Uber dropped a pretty big bombshell recently, didn't they? Said they'd comply with California's A B five and reclassify their drivers as employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the company believes its workers will still be classified correctly under the new measure, West said Uber will not be automatically reclassifying drivers to be employees in January, when the measure is likely to take effect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that, and I was like, wait, *what*? This is a massive shift for them. But then, like, immediately after, they're like, "Oh, by the way..."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that, and I was like, wait, what? This is a massive shift for them. But then, like, immediately after, they're like, Oh, by the way...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] "...we've set aside thirty million dollars for a ballot measure!" To, uh, essentially strip those same workers of any benefits. It's wild, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...we've set aside thirty million dollars for a ballot measure! To, uh, essentially strip those same workers of any benefits. It's wild, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uber says it is prepared to fight any legal challenges in court and has set aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure to provide workers with other benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a classic Uber move. Tony West, their chief legal officer, made it pretty clear they're not stopping the fight in arbitration or court, either. This is just, like, a tactical maneuver.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a classic Uber move. Tony West, their chief legal officer, made it pretty clear they're not stopping the fight in arbitration or court, either. This is just, like, a tactical maneuver.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect we will continue to respond to claims of misclassification in arbitration and in court as necessary, just as we do now, Tony West, Ubers chief legal officer, told reporters during a press call on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And their whole argument hinges on them believing they won't meet the standards of the stricter employment test set by AB5.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And their whole argument hinges on them believing they won't meet the standards of the stricter employment test set by A B five.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ubers argument hinges on the belief that it will meet the standards of the stricter employment test set forth by the bill. ... Just because the test is hard, it doesnt mean we will not be able to pass it, West said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kinda ironic, because AB5 says if the work is part of your main business, or you control it, they're employees. And Uber's main business *is* drivers and rides, you know? That's where all the profits come from.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kinda ironic, because A B five says if the work is part of your main business, or you control it, they're employees. And Uber's main business is drivers and rides, you know? That's where all the profits come from.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uber argues its main business is not drivers and rides, but being a technology platform for several different types of digital marketplaces.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And they actively force drivers to be signed into multiple services at once, like Lyft and food delivery. So, control? Check.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And they actively force drivers to be signed into multiple services at once, like Lyft and food delivery. So, control? Check.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also allows drivers to be signed into multiple services, from Lyft to food delivery companies, at once.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so they're just gonna automatically reclassify drivers in January, but only because they *believe* they'll still be wrongly classified under the new rules. It's so convoluted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so they're just gonna automatically reclassify drivers in January, but only because they believe they'll still be wrongly classified under the new rules. It's so convoluted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the company believes its workers will still be classified correctly under the new measure, West said Uber will not be automatically reclassifying drivers to be employees in January, when the measure is likely to take effect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And, of course, Uber and Lyft stock both closed in the red on the news. Even Governor Newsom is apparently in talks with them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And, of course, Uber and Lyft stock both closed in the red on the news. Even Governor Newsom is apparently in talks with them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: This feels like such a throwback to their earliest days, doesn't it? Just constantly trying to avoid regulatory red tape, pretending existing laws didn't apply to them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This feels like such a throwback to their earliest days, doesn't it? Just constantly trying to avoid regulatory red tape, pretending existing laws didn't apply to them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ubers defiant stance is a throwback to its earliest days of ride-hailing where it made similar arguments that existing laws around taxis and transportation also didnt apply to its business.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The whole gig economy, really, was built on *not* having to provide benefits, healthcare, or set schedules.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The whole gig economy, really, was built on not having to provide benefits, healthcare, or set schedules.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The gig economy was largely built off companies from Uber to TaskRabbit to DoorDash utilizing independent employees who could set their own schedules, but didnt receive benefits like healthcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Tony West, he even said something kinda telling. Like, "Just because the test is easy, it doesn't mean we will not be able to fail it."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Tony West, he even said something kinda telling. Like, Just because the test is easy, it doesn't mean we will not be able to fail it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just because the test is hard, it doesnt mean we will not be able to pass it, West said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, implying they're *trying* to fail it to prove a point about their business model. It's pretty cynical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, implying they're trying to fail it to prove a point about their business model. It's pretty cynical.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And, um, Uber's not alone in this. Lyft is coordinating with them and also committed thirty million dollars to that ballot measure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And, um, Uber's not alone in this. Lyft is coordinating with them and also committed thirty million dollars to that ballot measure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of its response, Uber is also coordinating with its rival Lyft to propose a new ballot measure... Lyft, who also committed $30 million to the ballot measure, said the state had missed an important opportunity when it came to regulating the space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's a united front to, like, legally undercut the very thing they're publicly complying with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's a united front to, like, legally undercut the very thing they're publicly complying with.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They're taking this fight directly to the California voters to preserve their independent contractor model, hoping to get fewer benefits for their workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They're taking this fight directly to the California voters to preserve their independent contractor model, hoping to get fewer benefits for their workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are fully prepared to take this issue to the voters of California to preserve the freedom and access drivers and riders want and need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fascinating stuff, as always, with these guys.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fascinating stuff, as always, with these guys.
